loans.name: Zerish

texts.en:
Zerish is a member of the Ikweta East borrower group,she is 27 years old woman,she is married.

Zerish started her own shop business selling commodities like rice,wheat,2 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 50,000 Tsh.

This is Zerishi`s first loan from BRAC.She requested the amount of 250,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice,wheat,sugar for her business.

With the profit she gain from the use of this loan Zerish hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice,soup,cooking oil

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly D. is already 46 years old. She is a vendor of salted eggs in their rural village of Cebu in San Isidro, Isabela. Since making salted eggs is one of the products made in their place, there are a lot of salted-egg vendors who serve as her competitors.

As to Merly, her simple enterprise is of big help in sustaining the needs of her family, especially her three children of whom two already graduated from college while the youngest is still studying.

Through the income that she generates from vending, she is able to send her children to school. However, she wants to further improve her business to enable her to save for the education of her youngest child. Aside from that she also wants improve her family’s living conditions through the income that she generates from her business.

Merly wants to borrow PHP 5,000 from Kiva as additional business capital. She is glad because her husband is always at her side, especially in times of trial.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her business

texts.en: Elizabeth D. is from the village of Canibungan Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, is married, and has four adult children. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month. In 2004, Elizabeth joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Elizabeth is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 16th from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda S. is from the village of Curvada, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 42 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Erlinda owns and operates a business making and selling food, primarily preparing and selling banana cue (plantain, fried in boiling oil and held on a skewer) in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Erlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to pay for the tuition of her children. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Silvinio

texts.en:
“Managing the business wisely is very important to every entrepreneur,” said Silvinio D. C.. For twenty years now, he has been a caterer and at the same time has managed a gown-for-rent business in the simple town of Ramon, Isabela. He did not finish his studies but really works hard to succeed in his own way.

Up to now, Silvinio has been able to expand his business in Cauayan City and is looking forward to further expansion and business development. According to him, managing the business gives him joy in life thus he really wants to make his business successful by giving to it his full effort and sacrifice.

His need of financial capital encouraged Silvinio to borrow PHP 40,000 that will serve as his additional capital for his growing business. He hopes that Kiva lenders will give him the opportunity to further improve his business and at the same time help others by providing them with a job.

Silvinio is glad that he is able to serve and help other people through his business. He is still single thus he spends his income by helping the education of his siblings and by providing for the needs of his parents.

loans.use: To use as additional business capital

loans.name: Ndiuka C Group

texts.en:
Pendo is a member of the Ndiuka C borrower group,she is 40 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 1 child,Her child is aged 12 years.

Pendo started her clothing business selling kanga and vitenge(fabric) 3 years ago,she works 6 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 250,000 Tsh.

This is Pendo`s first loan from BRAC.She requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more Fabric for sale.
        
With the profit she gain from the use of this loan Pendo hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Frora is another member of the same borrower group,she also requested loan amount 100,000 Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more vitenge,and kanga(fabric)

loans.name: Grater's Group

texts.en:
Grater S., age 37, is single with two children aged 18 and 16 years. She has a cosmetics shop which she started a year and a half ago. She works daily from 8 a.m. until 8 p.m. and is able to earn a monthly profit of around $50.

This will be Grater’s 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to buy more cosmetics and has paid it back successfully. She hopes for a new loan to further increase her business.

Grater will share this loan with her loan group, Uwazi na Ukweli, which totals twenty members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Grater is in the middle in a blue blouse.

loans.use: To increase her business

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta S. makes a living by preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. She is from the village of Maningcol, Ozamis City, Misamis Occidental. She is 58 years old, married and has two adult children. Violeta has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Violeta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Violeta has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Violeta is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be her fifth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Ndika C Group

texts.en:
Maria is a member of the Ndiuka C borrower group,she is 45 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 5 children.Her children are aged 22,18,15,13 and 10 years.

Maria started her own grocery business selling soda,beer 4 years ago,she works 10 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tsh.

This is Maria`s first loan from BRAC.She requested the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more soda and beer.
With the profit she gain from the use of this loan Maria hopes to save more money and expand her business.
Estelina is another member of the same borrower group,she requested loan from BRAC 200,000 Tsh in order to expand her business

loans.use: To buy more soda,beer

loans.name: Bulubandi East Babirye Zaija Group

texts.en:
B. Zaija, age 26, has had a retail business for four years. She is using this loan to purchase items such as sugar, flour, biscuits, bread, cooking oil, soap, salt, candles, match boxes, etc. to add stock to her business. She is married with two children in school.

B. Zaija represents her group. She keeps on encouraging her group members to work hard. She is a hardworking business lady whose dream is to obtain a plot of land and to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase retail items to add stock to a business

loans.name: Cagrielo Group

texts.en:
Arapha is a member of the Cagrielo borrower group,she is 38 years old woman,she married and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 14,9 years,she also cares for other 2 dependents.

Arapha started her own cafe business selling food 5 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 250,000 Tsh.

This is Arapha`s fist loan from BRAC.She requested loan amount 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice,cooking oil for her business.

With the profit she gain from the use of this loan Arapha hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Yunith is another member of the same borrower group,she requested loan amount 300,000 Tsh to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice,cooking ol,sugar

loans.name: Bulubandi East Lutabigi Sarah Group

texts.en:
L. Sarah, age 28, is the owner of a salon since the year 2004. She is a married business lady, blessed with two children and looking after six dependents who are all in school. She is requesting a loan to purchase salon items such as hair chemicals, hair treatments, conditioners and equipment like rollers, combs and so forth to provide quality services to her customers.

L. Sarah represents her group. She is an inspiring business lady whose dream is to purchase a plot of land and construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase salon items

loans.name: Perfecta

texts.en:
Perfecta B. owns and operates a sari-sari, or general store, selling daily use products such as soap, shampoo, toothpaste, etc. She is 63 years old, married and has six adult children. She is from the village of Cabolanonan, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. Perfecta has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Perfecta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Perfecta has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 5,905 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her second loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding a sari-sari store

loans.name: Tijore

texts.en:
Tijore J. is currently in the business of selling fruits such as mangoes, guava, oranges etc. and vegetables like cabbages,okra, etc. She is requesting a loan to purchase a fridge for keeping her fruits longer. Tijore is 30 years old and is widowed because her husband was one of the SPLA guerrillas and died in the liberation war which lasted for two decades. She has 2 children and her children go to school.

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a machine for crushing fruits into juice.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase a fridge for keeping fruits longer

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en:
Chhum Y. is a 56-year-old local farmer and is the good father of seven children: four of them are single and the others are married and have already started new homes.

Presently, Chhum Y. is a consultant adviser in the village. On the other hand, he and his wife have always cultivated a variety of natural crops for additional income. Beside this, Chhum Y. has always raised a pig in a stall that he built but, due to his income not being enough to continue raising, that is why he has stopped this operation.

Right now, Chhum Y. hopes to invest in his pig-raising business again; thus, he has decided to seek a loan of $500 on Kiva. He will use his loan to buy pig food and piglets to raise, as well as to buy fertilizer for growing his crop.

loans.use: To buy pig food and piglets to raise, as well as to buy fertilizer for his crop

loans.name: Maria Nelfie

texts.en:
Maria Nelfie P. is from the village of Catadman, Manabay, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 23 years old. Maria Nelfie is single. To make a living, Maria Nelfie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a sari-sari or general store.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Maria Nelfie has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Maria Nelfie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Nelfie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering and to invest in a new business such as snack vending. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Maria Nelfie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering and to invest in new business such as snack vending

loans.name: Bulubandi 1 West Mukaya Olivia Group

texts.en:
M. Olivia is twenty-eight years old and married with four children, three of whom are going to school. She is also looking after two dependents.

Olivia has owned a retail shop since 2005. She is requesting the loan to purchase retail items; that is, adding stock to her business such as flour, rice, salt, sweets (candies), biscuits (cookies), soap, juice, air-time, etc.

Olivia is planning to work hard so that she improves her retail shop. Her future hope is to educate her children and obtain another business which will help her generate extra daily income to cater for her family.

loans.use: To purchase items for her shop

With the profit she gain from the use of this loan Frola hopes to save more money and expand her business.
Catheline is another member of the same borrower group,she requested loan amount 200,000 Tsh from BRAC in order to expand her saloon business

texts.en: M. Aslam is the group leader of M. Aslam group. There are three members in this group. Each of them would like to take a loan for his or her business. M. Aslam would like a loan for his general store. Mahy Gull would like a loan for her tailoring business. Farzana would like a loan for her husband who has a fruit and vegetable shop. So, they are requesting a group loan of 15,000 Afghani. They are very happy with this loan process in Afghanistan.

She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. loans.name: Bulubandi 1 West Kagoya Wantati Group

texts.en:
K. Wantati owns a milling machine which she has been operating for three years. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of maize for milling into maize flour for sale. She is the mother of five children (one child is still studying) and she takes care of three dependents going to school too.

K. Wantati represents her group and she encourages her fellow women to be creative and knowledgeable always. She is an active business woman whose dream is to construct a house and educate her children.

loans.name: Cagrielo Group

texts.en:
Frola is a member of the Cagrilo borrower group,she is 27 years old woman.She is married and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 7 and 2 years.

 Frola started her own saloon business 3 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 180,000 Tsh.

This is Frola`s first loan from BRAC.she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy commodities for her business.

With the profit she use from the use of this loan Frola hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Elizabeth is another member of the same borrower group,she requested loan amount 3200,000 from BRAC in order to expand her clothing business

loans.name: Teang

texts.en: Fishing is the most important part of 29-year-old C.’s daily work. She and her husband have been living their life on a fishing boat on the river for more than nine years. This couple wake up every morning, drive their boat toward the middle of river and then fish. After the fishing is done, they hurry to bring their fish to the market and sell to their regular buyers on credit. They will collect their money after their buyers finish selling the fish. Recently, this family can’t catch as many fish as before, because their boat is often broken. Therefore, C. is applying for a loan to repair the old boat and to buy new tools to replace some of their old tools that are ruined.

loans.use: To repair an old fishing boat and to buy new tools

loans.name: Bulubandi 1 West Nakasolo Madina Group

texts.en: N. Madina is an active business lady. Her hope is to work hard, prosper and educate her children. She is using the loan for brickmaking,  that is purchasing firewood for burning bricks, paying workers, transporting the bricks to convenient places for sale, and so forth. She has been in her business for two years and she sincerely wishes to enlarge her business so that she can make more bricks for big markets and therefor earn more profit. N. Madina is married with five children; two go to school. She is also looking after one dependent, who is also going to school.

loans.use: For brick making,that is purchasing firewood for burning bricks, paying the workers, transporting the bricks to convenient places for sale, and so forth.

loans.name: Isidra

texts.en:
Isidra R. is from the town of Calabayan, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 52, widowed and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Isidra owns & operates a business making & selling food snacks to the local community. Isidra has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Isidra joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Isidra is requesting a oan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients to make food snacks. This will be her first loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Samoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Samoeun S., 37, and her husband, Mr. Sam-at Kloeng, 35, were married in 1994 and have three sons. All of them are in local school.  She lives with her parents on an Island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Samoeun has been a silk weaver since she was 15 years old. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in a market located in Phnom Penh. Mr. Sam-at Kloeng is a construction worker who builds wooden houses  Samoeun’s father is a constuction contractor. He lacks some money to run his business, so Samoeun is asking for a loan of $1,000 to help her father’s business.

loans.use: To help her father’s business.

loans.name: Ndiuka C Group

texts.en:
Edwick is a member of the Ndiuka borrower group,she is 48 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 5 children.Her children are aged 24,22,18,14,10 years.

 Edwick started her own business selling local beer 7 years ago,she works 10 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 80,000 Tsh.

 This is Edwick`s first loan from BRAC.She requested loan amount 200,000 in order to buy more commodities to her business.

With the profit she gain from the use of this loan Edwick hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Agusta is another member of the same borrower group she requested loan amount 200,000 Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities

loans.name: Hadji

texts.en:
Hadji P. is from the town of Calabayan, Ozamiz City. He is 28, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Hadji owns & operates a motorcycle transportation service. Hadji has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 1000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Hadji joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hadji is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP; this will be his first loan from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: to expand the business

loans.name: Thach

texts.en:
Mrs. Thach L., 55, and her husband, Mr. Yun Choun, 56, live on an island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1972 and have four sons. One son is married and lives in a separate home, and two other sons help their father in his wooden house construction business.

Thach has been a silk weaver since she was 15 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Yun Choun has been building wooden houses for over twenty years. His business now is running very well and he needs some more materials to support his operation, but lacks money for this.
Thus, Thach is requesting a loan of US$1,000 to purchase one more wood-cutting machine, to help expand her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase one wood-cutting machine to help expand her husband’s wooden house construction business.

loans.name: Joemar

texts.en:
Joemar L. is from the village of Lupagan, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 33, married and has 1 infant. To make a living, Joemar owns & operates a business. He plants and harvests rice for sale. Joemar has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Joemar joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joemar is requesting a loan of 20000 PHP; his first from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Raksmey

texts.en:
Mrs. Raksmey K., 22, and her husband, Mr. Thang Thong, 26, were married in 2006 and have a young daughter. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Raksmey has been a silk weaver since she was 12 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. Her husband has been a horse cart driver for 2 years. He is also a fisherman. Raksmey is requesting her first loan of $200 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business and to buy a boat and fishing nets for her husband’s fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business and to buy a boat and fishing nets for her husband’s fishing business.

loans.name: Kuyendu

texts.en:
Kuyendu R. brews and sells local alcohol wholesale. She is requesting a loan to purchase more brewing materials in order to improve her business. Kuyendu is 40 and her husband is a businessman at the Konyokonyo market. They have two children who attend school at Gumbo Primary School. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up her brewery.  

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase brewing materials

loans.name: It's Group

texts.en:
These are four low-income people who are jointly requesting a group loan. One of them, It N., is 31. She was  selected to be the leader by the other members. She owns an old medium-sized  boat that she and her husband use to fish. The family always wakes up when the sky is still dark in order to prepare their equipment to fish in and around the Tunle Sap River, which is the best place to catch fish. It N. said that she tries to work hard and never wastes time at her business activities, but unfortunately she recently had to face the fact that some of her fishing equipment was ruined. Because of that obstacle, It N. is requesting a loan to repair her equipment and to buy more essential tools. The family has four school-aged children and they also help with fishing when they are not studying. The other borrowers are:
Chat T., a fisherman, who asking for a loan to add to his saving, so that he can build a new small house; 
Leng O., who will be using the loan to repair and decorate her old house; and 
Leng H., who requests a loan to enlarge her fish-selling business.

loans.use: To repair and buy more essential tools

loans.name: Ndiuka C Group

texts.en:
Devotha is a member of the Ndiuka C borrower group,she is 36 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 3 children.Her children are aged 16,13 and 8 years.

 Devotha started her own business selling local beer 10 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tsh.

This is Devotha first loan from BRAC.She requested loan amount 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities like wheat,sugar  for her business.

With the profit she gain from the use of this loan Devotha hopes to save more money and expand her business.
Shida is another member of the same borrower group,she requested loan amount 250,000 Tsh in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more wheat,sugar

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanna S., 45 (shown in the picture with one of her daughters), and her husband, Mr. Thy Chann, 47, were married in 1990 and have three children - one son and two daughters. One is a garment factory worker and other two attend school. The family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about 25 kilometers from the capital. 

Vanna has been selling roasted corn for five months. Her husband has been a mason since 1999. She wants to purchase a motorbike for commuting, but she doesn’t have money for this. Thus, Vanna is requesting her first loan of $800.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for commuting.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For growing corn

loans.name: Bulubandi 1 West Mugozi Margaret Group

texts.en: M. Margaret has been in the poultry business since 2001 – eight years in her business. She is a 30-year-old married business lady blessed with three children, all going to school. She is using this loan to purchase chicks, drugs and feed. She is working very hard to improve upon her business by stocking more chicken feed and so forth. Her hope for the future is to educate her children, enlarge her business, construct a house and, even more, she would love to drive. She wants to at least have a change in her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase chicks, drugs and feed for a poultry business

loans.name: Then

texts.en:
Mrs. Then T., 29, and her husband, Mr. Then Lang, 33, were married in 1998 and have two young children: one son and one daughter. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.


Mrs. Then T. has been a garment factory worker for a year. Her husband has been a construction worker for twelve years. Recently, he wants to change to a new business and drive a Tuk Tuk, a motorbike with a trailer at the back. So she requests her first loan of $600 to add to her own money to purchase a trailer for her husband to drive a Tuk Tuk taxi.

loans.use: To add to her own money to purchase a trailer for her husband to drive as a Tuk Tuk taxi.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For growing corn

loans.name: Ndiuka C Group

texts.en:
Zamoyoni is a member of the Ndiuka C borrower group,she is 24 years old,she is married and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 3 and 1 years.

Zamoyoni started her own food clothing business selling clothes 2 years ago,she works 8 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximate 100,000 Tsh.

This is Zamoyono`s first loan from BRAC.she requested loan amount 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes for sale.

With the profit she gain from the use of this loan Zamoyoni hopes to save more money and expand her business.
Fikiria is another member of the same borrower group,she requested loan amount 250,000 Tsh in order to expand her clothing business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For growing peanuts

loans.name: Bulubandi North Namukasa Jessica Group

texts.en: N. Jessica is 24 and married. She has one child and is also a guardian of two school-aged children. She has been a tailor for three years. She is requesting a loan to purchase material for making dresses, suits, bicycle seats, etc.  She is very willing to work very hard and improve upon her business, and she wants eventually to own a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase material for making dresses, suits, bicycle seats, etc.

loans.name: Angel

texts.en:
Angel S. is from the village of Gata Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 44, married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Angel owns & operates a business providing transport services to local community members. Angel has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 1994, Angel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Angel repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from GDMPC. Angel is requesting his second  loan of 10000 PHP, which he will use to repair his vehicles for better service. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair his vehicles for better service

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is 23 and single. He owns a bakery store in Nabatiyeh (South Lebanon). He requests $700 in order to buy basic ingredients that allow him to continue working. Ali sells traditional Lebanese pastries such as Mankeesh and Lahmbaajeen and also some not-so-traditional dishes, such as pizza. This is Ali's second loan cycle with Al Majmoua.  Ali's future plan is to expand the store.

loans.name: Louise

texts.en:
Greetings from K. LOUSE  in Gasabo District, Kigali city, the capital of Rwanda . KABHIRE is 44, married, and has 7 children: 20, 18, 16, 14, 12, 9, and 5 years old. She also take care of another person who is 23.

She has owned a spare parts shop  for 3 years and employs 1 person to help run the business.  She works every day from 7:30 a.m. to 18:00 p.m. and earns a profit of approximately 250,000 Rwandan Francs per month .  She requests a loan of 500000 Rwf and with the increased profits, K. hopes to  expand her business.

loans.use: Expanding her store

loans.name: Ipogolo Group

Suzana is a member of the Ipogolo borrower group.she is 30 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children,Her children are aged12,14 years.

Suzana started her own business selling local beer 5 years ago,she works 11 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tsh.

This is Suzana`s first loan from BRAC.She requested loan amount 200,000 In order to buy more commodities like wheat,sugar for her business.

With the profit she gain from the use of this loan Suzana hopes to save more money and expand her business.

Modesta is another member of the same borrower group,she requested loan amount 200,000 in order to expand her own food business.

texts.en: N. Hasifa is 23,  married, has two children and also looks after two dependents. She has owned a bakery for 5 years. She is requesting a loan to buy more equipment, ingredients and so forth. She is a hardworking business lady whose dream is to purchase a plot of land.

loans.use: To improve her bakery business and buy more equipment, ingredients and so forth.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en: Mohammad is 37, married and has 3 children. He is a carpenter in the southern town of Nabatiyeh and requests $2,000 to buy wood. He has been in business for more than 10 years and he is skilled at what he does. He has clients from all over South Lebanon. His main difficulty was to find a place to work and his future goal is to expand his business.

loans.use: Wood

loans.name: Awoussi

texts.fr: cette femmme est une résidente du quartier de gbossimé à Lomé, elle est mariée et est mère de 02 enfants, elle fait le commerce de sacs de maïs, voulant agrandir son commerce elle sollicite un prêt de WAGES pour acheter 30 sacs de maïs, elle vend son produit dans le marché local de son quartier.
texts.en:
This is a woman who resides in the Gbossimé district in Lomé. She is married and the mother of two children. She has a business selling corn. However, wanting to expand her commerce, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 30 sacks of corn. She sells her merchandise at the local marketplace in her district.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For buying sacks of corn

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou S. is from the village of Panay Daku, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 46, married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marilou owns & operates a business providing tricycle transport services to the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marilou joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Marilou is requesting her 4th loan, for 5336 PHP, which will be used to repair her vehicles for better service. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Juliana A.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! Here we present Juliana M. from Mbozi. She is 30, married and has four children, between the ages of  8 and 15. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependent who is an orphan.
Juliana has been running a shoe business since 2006. She buys material, such as leather,  and make shoes to sell.
She works at her business for 13 hours a day, 7 days a week, and is assisted by her husband. Juliana earns about 230USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more materials in bulk.  In the future, she plans to increase the stock for her business. Juliana thanks you for your support!
ABOUT SELFINA:
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more material in bulk

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 30 year old Ruth M. from Mbozi. She is married with four children between the ages of 2 and 10. Ruth has been running a Mama Lishe business since 2006. Café/Mama Lishe - A mama lishe (local restaurant or café) in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough made from maize flour), plantains (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces.

She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by three employees. Ruth currently earns about 120 USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to pay rent for several months. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of her business. Ruth thanks you for your support!

ABOUT SELFINA: SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To pay rent for several months

loans.name: Jihad

texts.en:
Jihad, a 45 year old father of two, owns a gift shop in Nabatiyeh, South Lebanon. He requests a $1,000 loan to cover some bills he had to pay for fixing his store. This is Jihad's second cycle with Al Majmoua and the first cycle had a really good impact on the business.

Jihad sells his products to people all over Nabatiyeh. Even though he has had financial difficulties during the past, Jihad hopes to expand the gift shop and improve his business.

loans.use: Store maintenance

loans.name: Anonymous

loans.name: Bulubandi North Waida Elizabeth Group

texts.en:
W. Elizabeth is fifty years old and married with eight children, of whom two are still in school, and she is taking care of two dependants who are also going to school. She deals with rice and she has been in her business for one year.

She wants to lift her business from where it is to another level. She is using the loan to purchase more bags of rice for sale. She is an encouraging and hardworking business woman whose dream is to construct a house and have a good life.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of rice for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For buying a hair dryer and other equipment for work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more fish in bulk for reselling

loans.name: Jalal

texts.en:
Jalal is 24 years old and he is married. He works as an interior designer and he cleans tiles. He's been in this business for eight years and he acquired his skills throughout the years while working with his father.

Jalal is committed, punctual and concentrates on his work. His future plan is to open an interior decoration company and attract more clients. Jalal requests $1,500 to fix his house in the suburbs of Beirut.

loans.use: To fix his house

loans.name: Mrs. Saren Eam Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank, which consists of twenty-four people, is located in Slab Ta Aon village in Kandal province. Mrs. Saren E. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members.

Mrs. Saren E. has four children two of whom are firewood sellers in the local village and the others are too young to work or study because they are at the age of two and four years old. Her husband, Mr. Meas Sophy, works in the Disabled People Center.

Mrs. Saren E. owns a small restaurant in the local village where she sells Chinese noodles. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more ingredients for her business.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for her  business

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen R. currently sells beer at her bar and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell. Hellen is 42 years old and married to a security guard. She has three children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she intends to build a house for rent. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok R. has been sustaining her family’s living conditions for years by planting a variety of crops. She is aged 26 and the mother of three teenage children who are going to school. She is married to Theoun, 33, a fisherman.

Sok R. presently grows crops such as cucumbers, cabbages, morning glories, etc. She estimates that she will sell her mature produce after another month. Unfortunately, her crops are not growing well because they still need fertilizer. Sok R. is thus requesting a Kiva loan of $250 to purchase more fertilizer to fatten her crop yield. She proposes to use the rest of loan for her husband to repair his fishing equipment.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer to fatten her crop yield and to pay for repair of her husband's fishing equipment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more crops in bulk

In 2005, Charlene joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from GDMPC. Charlene is requesting a new loan of 10,900 PHP which will be used to purchase materials to improve her business. This loan will be her ninth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials to improve her business

loans.name: Bulubandi North Zaina Kagoya Group

texts.en:
Zaina K. is thirty-five years old and she is representing her group. She is a married lady who is blessed with five children of whom three are going to school. She works very hard to educate her children.

Zaina has a business dealing in matooke (bananas) which she has been operating for over five years. She is using the loan to purchase matooke from deep villages to bring to town to sell.

loans.use: To purchase matooke from deep villages

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is married with two children. He repairs and paints car bodies in the suburbs of Beirut and he requests $2,000 to buy a welding machine. Ali thinks that this loan will change his life. This machine will help him improve his business and will attract more customers as well as make the repairing process more efficient.

Ali has been working in this business for eight years and he hopes to expand and improve his work in terms of space and quality. He is experienced at what he does. He is honest and he treats clients well and fairly.

loans.name: Mrs. Sokheng Toch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twenty people who live in Slab Ta Aon village in Kandal province have formed a village bank. The bank president, selected by the members, is Mrs. Sokheng T.. All the members will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Sokheng T. owns a small grocery store in the village. Since this business is going well, she plans to expand it by seeking a loan to buy more grocery goods for her current business. She hopes to increase her income in order to provide better living conditions for her family. Her husband, Mr. Kham Sokhom, is a construction worker who makes a small income to support the family. Mrs. Sokheng T. is 36-years old and the mother of four children one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To purchase groceries

loans.name: Zaynab

texts.en: Zaynab is 26-years old and owns a store in the suburbs of Beirut. She sells women's clothing and is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy more products . She has owned the store since 2007 and she hopes the loan will help to expand the store and increase profits. Her business has faced difficulties in the past when she had few clients and products but she hopes to produce more in order to overcome her financial difficulties. Zaynab is a hard worker and has good people skills which help her in running her business and improving it.

loans.use: To purchase clothing

loans.name: Natalia

texts.en:
Natalia is married with two teenage daughters. She sells women's clothing at the central market in Pavlograd. Her net income is about 3,500 UAH per month.

Natalia has been in this business for one year. She had a low salary at her previous work place and decided to quit her job and start working for herself. Even though it is more difficult, her efforts have been paid back with results. Natalia's business goal is to add men's clothing and improve her business conditions.

Natalia would like to borrow 10,150 UAH to increase the assortment of clothing available. She hopes to increase sales and invest income back into developing her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothing

loans.name: Rehema H.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Tanzania! This is 25-year old Rehema J. from Mbozi. Rehema is married with two children, aged 4 and 7. She is also responsible for supporting two orphan children.

Since 2007, Rehema has been running a business selling rice. She purchases rice whole sale and then resells it in the retail market to get profits. She works at the business for 9 to 12 hours per day, six days per week and is assisted by her husband. Rehema currently earns about 200USD a month. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more bulk rice bags. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity of her business. Rehema thanks you for your support!

loans.name: Mrs. Yat Mao Group Loan

texts.en:
Mrs. Yat M. is the group leader of five people who are all living in Srah Trakuon village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Yat M. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living. On this plantation, she now faces a small problem because her field is infertile. So she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive. She would use the rest of the money to hire a laborer to plow the field.

Mrs. Yat M. has five children two of whom are employed in different jobs while the others are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Moeuk Hon, helps her in the plantation.

All the members of this group loan have end-of-term (EoT) loans so they are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loans term. EoT loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and to hire a laborer to plow the field

loans.use: To purchase more car oil to meet the demand of her customers.

Greetings from Mazimpaka J. C. in Gasabo District, Kigali city, the capital of Rwanda. Mazimpaka is 34 years old; he is married without children.

Mazimpaka owns a spare parts shop where he sells his products. He has owned the business for 6 years and employs one person who helps him with the business. He works every day from 7:00am to 19:00pm and earns a profit of approximately 150,000 RWF per month.

loans.name: Matilda E.

texts.en:
Mambo (Greetings!) from Matilda S. from Mbozi, Tanzania! Matilda is 40 years old, divorced with three children between the ages of 22 and 26. Matilda has been running a mama lishe business since 2007. A mama lishe (local restaurant or café) in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches. The food is all local; rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantains (a cooked savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of sauces.

Matilda works at the business 16 hours a day, 7 days a week, and is assisted by her daughter. Matilda currently earns about 60USD a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase more rice, beans, salt, sugar and maize flour in bulk. 

In the future, she plans to open a new location. Matilda thanks you for your support!

About SELFINA

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more rice, beans, salt, sugar, and maize flour in bulk
