Lilia is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lilia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Because of her soap-making business, Salvacion A., 51, literally lives a fragrant life. She and her retired husband Serafin, 58, live with 2 of their 6 children (4 are already married). She has been mixing her own detergent soap, fabric softener and liquid dishwashing soap in her own backyard in Maricaban, Pasay City for the last 4 years. She does this all by herself. Salvacion earns a monthly income of P18,000.00 through the sale of these cleaning commodities.

Salvacion has just finished paying off her previous loan with CCT and is now applying for a new loan to purchase raw materials for soap making. She longs to have a place in a commercial center where she can sell her products. She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005 and has since been receiving “blessings from heaven.” Salvacion is very thankful for God’s continued provisions even in the midst of crisis (her father has just been paralyzed).

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: raw materials for soap making

loans.name: Jesica

texts.en:
Jesica has been involved in her rice retailing business for six months. Aside from that, she is engaged in vegetable vending for additional income in order to provide for the needs of her family.

She is now requesting a loan amounting to PHP 5,000, which she will use to buy sacks of rice for her retailing business. She believes that even though there are difficulties in life, one must still have strong faith to surpass those trials. She dreams of having a more comfortable life, a dream she considers attainable as long as she works diligently. She knows that she will generate more income by having a sufficient supply of rice because rice is a basic staple for everyone.

Jesica is married to Roberto, who is also a farmer. They have three children, all of whom go to school. Jesica and Roberto hope that their children will all become successful and achieve their dreams.

The family resides in the remote village of Casilagan Ilagan, Isabela.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her rice retailing business

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en:
Mrs. Sareth V. lives in the village of Pam in the province of Takeo. She is a farmer in the local village. Aside from this plantation, she is a pig breeder.

For the first plantation, she now faces a small problem because the soil in her field has become infertile. She decided to ask for a loan in order to buy more fertilizers to support the field so as to make her crop more productive. She plans to use the rest of the loan to buy more piglets and pig food to support her second business.

Mrs. Sareth V. is 42 years old and the mother of five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Bin Munyra, is a village chief who earns a small salary to support the family. Her husband is presented on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers to support the field

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn F. is from the village of Curvada, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 40 years old and is married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a "sari-sari" or general store. She sells both food and daily use products in this local community store and has been engaged in her business for over a year, earning approximately 2,500 PHP a month..

In 2009, Jocelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. She wished to help improve her living situation and to increase her ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn is requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Jocelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to pay tuition for her children.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Thath

texts.en:
Mrs. Thath N. is a farmer in the village of Sras Takuon in the province of Takeo. She is a widow with three children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the youngest one is attending the local school.

Since rice farming cannot provide a better living, she has decided to switch careers. She has decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike with a cart. Her goal is to transport people from one place to another for an income.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike in order to start up a transportation business

loans.name: Chanthou

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthou N. is a villager in the village of Sambuor in the province of Takeo. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Mao Yuthea, is a plough maker in the local village. Since this business is going well, Mrs. Chanthou N. has decided to ask for a loan in order to buy more timber so that her husband can make more ploughs to sell.

Mrs. Chanthou N. is 25 years old and has two small children, ages one and two. Her husband is presented at the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy timber for her husband's plough-making business

loans.name: Sherlit

Sherlit has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2005, Sherlit joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and to increase her ability to engage in business activities. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house.

loans.name: Nut

texts.en:
Nut R. is 68 years old and a resident of the city of Phnom Penh, where she earns a living planting vegetables on her own land. She then harvests and sells her mature product in bulk to market vendors. She is a widow with one daughter. Her daughter is married and earns an income sewing clothes for neighbors. She shares her income to provide for family needs.

Nut R. planted her crop a month ago, but her crops still need fertilizer to ensure growth. Because she lacks capital, she is applying for a loan from HKL in order to buy more fertilizers for increasing her crop yield. In addition, she will buy piglets so as to begin raising them for sale from her home.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers for increasing her crop yield

loans.name: Paugata's Group

texts.en:
Paugata T. is a 71-year-old woman living in the town of Papaloa, Sinamoga. She is married and has ten adult children.

Paugata owns and operates a weaving business, selling general hand-woven products to tourists and local community members. She has been engaged in this business for over four years.

In 2007, Paugata joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,500 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to make mats and mattresses.

Paugata is now requesting a new loan of 4,000 WST which will again be used to purchase raw materials to make mats and mattresses. The loan will be her 3rd from SPBD. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.


About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self-esteem.

loans.name: Bo

texts.en:
Bo S. and his wife are cooking suppliers; they also cook meals for neighbors' parties – especially wedding parties. He is 56 years old and his wife, Lang Som, is 52 years old. This couple was married years ago and they have five children: three children are married, and the other two are single and go to school and to work.

Bo S.’s current income is not enough to meet his family’s food needs. He hopes to operate a new business as a fruit seller during this coming fruit harvesting season, but he is lacking capital to do so. He is, therefore, looking for a loan in order to buy a large quantity of fruit from growers to resell for profit.

Bo S. and Lang Som are both in the photo.

texts.en:

She travels to buy them from her suppliers who are wholesale market suppliers. She generally generates an income of $5 per day, which provides her with income to help alleviate her family’s hard living conditions. Another source of income comes from her husband’s work: he is a military policeman and appears in the picture above.

Eang C. is skilled in sewing clothes, which she has done since before she was married, and she hopes to use these skills to provide a service for neighbors. Therefore, she would like to obtain a loan to purchase a machine and some sewing tools to begin her new business. The rest of the loan will allow her to buy more fruits to sell.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mr. Sok C., age 50, and his wife, Mrs. Ry Tey, age 49, live along National Road No. 1, about 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1980 and have nine children, four of whom are grown and married. Two of their daughters attend school and their very youngest child is still at home.

Sok has been a fisherman for 30 years. He fishes in the lake near his village. Mrs. Ry Tey sells the fish that her husband catches. Additionally, he also grows rice.

Sok doesn’t have enough fishing materials to operate his business, so he is requesting his first loan of $500 to purchase a boat and fishing nets. In addition, he will buy seeds for his farming business.

loans.use: To purchase a boat and fishing nets for his fishing business, and to buy seeds for farming.

loans.name: Apolinaria

texts.en: Mrs. Apolinaria T., 57 years of age, is married to Teodoro T., a farmer. The couple resides in P6 Dimaluna, Ozamiz City. They are blessed with three children who all have their own families at this time. Fortunately, one of her daughters had an opportunity to work abroad and now they receive monthly support for their daily needs. With a passion for business, they plan to open a little sari-sari store. Now, as a new member of PAGLAUM MPC, she is applying for a loan of PHP 5,000.00 as starting capital for their new business in order not to rely forever on the support of her daughter. The couple wishes that someday they can build a stall for their business, not like the little table and place they have now to display their goods.

loans.use: As starting capital for their sari-sari store
